messages.subject: Re: Another mei -- contined
messages.msgSnippet: Has anyone ever seen this sort of decoration on shakudo hitsu-ana plugs? ... Can t say I have seen a plug with that sort of elaborate design , but I do have a
messages.messageBody:
Has anyone ever seen this sort of decoration on shakudo hitsu-ana
plugs?
>
> http://zincavage.org/PineNeedleTsuba.html
>
>

Can't say I have seen a plug with that sort of elaborate design , but I
do have a tsuba with the kogai hitsu ana filled and a " continuation "
of the flower/grass design " cut " on the copper plug to " mask " the
hole.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Another mei -- contined
messages.msgSnippet: This is the tsuba which came in the Butterfly Tsukashi box.  I buy almost only iron tsukashi tsuba, but this one is the odd exception.  One hitsu-ana is
messages.messageBody:
This is the tsuba which came in the Butterfly Tsukashi box. I buy almost only iron tsukashi tsuba, but this one is the odd exception. One hitsu-ana is elaborately closed with shakuda featuring an unidentified plant in silver and cloisonné. Has anyone ever seen this sort of decoration on shakudo hitsu-ana plugs?

http://zincavage.org/PineNeedleTsuba.html


David Zincavage

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, April 21, 2005 8:03 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Another mei


It's right side up, but it's a motif rather than a mei. The radical for the first kanji is usually used for insects and some reptiles (no doubt other things, too)... it looks somewhat like cho (butterfly) 蝶. I'm sure that there are a lot of insect names that don't appear in our general J-E kanji dictionaries. The second kanji is sukashi透. What does the motif on the tsuba look like?

Jim



This was on the lid of a tsuba box which arrived with tsuba inside today. <sigh> I can't recognize any kanji as these in my copy of Nelson. (And I will be really embarassed if I scanned the image upside down.)

http://zincavage.org/TsubaBox.html
